Although this lab is not a traditional bacteriophage lab, students are encouraged to consider where naturally occurring phages are and where researchers may look for novel therapeutics. Students will form hypotheses, design an experiment, collect environmental water, or soil samples, and test them for bacteriophages.

pageData.text: Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. M. tuberculosis is developing resistance to many of the antibiotics that have traditionally been used to treat it. TB is an airborne pathogen and is transmitted from person to person. Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR/RR-TB) is a global health concern. According to the World Health Organization, there were between 119,000–264,000 deaths due to MDR/RR-TB in 2021.

In 2021, the Centers for Disease Control reported that there were almost 8,000 cases of TB in the U.S. The CDC reported that 71.4% of TB cases were among non-U.S.–born persons, and 28.2% of cases were reported among U.S.-born persons with the highest percentage of cases occurring among non-Hispanic Black or African American persons (34.1%). Health outcomes and the spread of infectious diseases can be influenced by various factors including socioeconomic status, access to healthcare, cultural and linguistic barriers, and quality of healthcare received. It is possible that these factors may affect health outcomes for minorities with MDR/RR-TB or TB. The potential for novel therapies, such as phage therapy, may help treat and reduce the spread of infections such as MDR/RR-TB.

pageData.text: are viruses that are often described as being “alien-like” (Figure 1), although not all phages are shaped like this. They infect and replicate within bacteria and archaea. In 1915, Dr. Twort described phages as “lesions in cultures of bacteria”. In 1917, Dr. D’Hérelle, a French-Canadian microbiologist researching dysentery, published the first paper describing the bacteriophage as a bacteria-eater (phagein "to devour"). He also observed that these phages had enormous potential to treat bacterial pathogens. Since the term “phage therapy” was first coined in 1921, research continued, and therapeutic uses were discovered. However, as the popularity of antibiotics grew, phage research was almost completely abandoned. As microbial continues to grow, there has been renewed interest in identifying phages that can be used as therapeutic treatments.

Phages do not infect human cells; many appear only to be able to infect specific microbial species, which is why there is hope that they can combat bacterial species that have developed . Phages have a few different strategies for infecting bacterial cells, including lytic, lysogenic, or . Each cycle begins with the attachment of the phage to the surface of the cell. The attachment is dependent on the presence of specific and this is what determines the specificity and host range of any given bacteriophage. The tailed phages (Figure 1) are thought to have the most potential in combating MDR bacteria as the receptors on their tails appear to be very specific and they are able to quickly kill the host cell.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Tailed phages have a head that contains DNA and tail, which makes the virus appear a little like an alien.

pageData.text: The is rapid and results in the production of new phages and death of the host bacterial cell (Figure 2). On agar plates, this lysis results in a where the cells have been killed. Figure 3 shows a plague that has been formed by Bacillus anthracis gamma phage. This gamma phage is 97% specific for Bacillus anthracis. The occurs when the phage injects its nucleic acid into the host. The phage genome either integrates into the microbial genome or exists as plasmids within the host cell. At this point, the phage is now referred to as a prophage. During lysogenic infections, the may alter the phenotype of the microbe. These alterations can provide the host microbes with enhanced colonization traits, antibiotic resistance, or production of toxins, which can be stable for thousands of generations. Under environmental stress, the prophage will leave the microbial genome and phage particles will be made and assembled, resulting in host cell lysis (Figure 2). are difficult to study and not well understood but during this type of infection the phage genome enters the cell in an unstable fashion and at some point, an environmental cue will trigger it to enter either the lysogenic or lytic cycle.

pageData.text: Until recently, phage research has focused on only a few model phages that primarily infected E. coli. These phages helped researchers advance the field of molecular biology, identify the basis of genetic material, understand that three nucleotides code for an amino acid, and the identification of restriction enzymes. With recent advancements in molecular technologies, it has become clear that phages play not only an important role in modern molecular biology but also in the environment. The refined techniques that have allowed researchers to purify and culture model phages in the lab require very specific growth requirements and may not be appropriate to apply to research that seeks to identify novel therapeutics for antibiotic-resistant or for understanding the abundance, diversity, and important functions they play in ecosystems.

Microorganisms play a fundamental role in all ecosystems. Microbial communities support key ecosystem services such as facilitating plant growth, recycling nutrients and organic matter, and regulating air and water quality. Together with plants, microbes regulate the global carbon and nitrogen cycles. Although not completely understood, phages play an important role in the biology of microbes. They are capable of not only infecting and killing their hosts but also facilitate <button class='glossary-text'>horizontal gene transfer</button> (HGT, non-sexual movement of genetic information between organisms). Through newly acquired genes, HGT contributes to the adaptation, survivability, and evolution of bacteria and archaea.

Phages exist in every ecosystem as part of the complex microbial community. <button class='glossary-text'>Bacteriophages</button> appear to be extremely stable in the environment, however in the lab, many are unstable and quickly lose <button class='glossary-text'>titre</button> (concentration). Traditionally, students in a virology laboratory class would be given a purified phage and susceptible host. However, in this investigation, you will perform an experiment in which you will attempt to culture phages from the environment.

typeBefore.title: Culture Recommendations (11 Steps)
typeBefore.text: You will need a relatively fresh liquid culture of Escherichia coli, Micrococcus luteus, Serratia marcesens, or Staphylococcus epidermidis for this investigation to be successful. Do not start Activity 1 until you have a viable liquid culture.

If you have reactivated cultures that are no more than two weeks days old, you may begin work on the Activities. If you need to transfer an older culture of bacterial strains, follow steps 1-11 below:

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, test tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture(s) from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment kit. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of the culture to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth and label the tube with the name of your culture.
Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.
Repeat steps 1-7 for any other cultures you will use in Activity 2.
Incubate the inoculated broth tubes upright in the rack with their caps slightly loose. Both organisms will grow at room temperature; however, they will grow faster around 37° C (99° F).
Extinguish the candle, disinfect the workspace with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.

Allow between 1 and 3 days of incubation for the broths to become turbid (cloudy). The length of time required for growth depends on the ambient temperature. Do not proceed until both cultures are growing well.
Note: Under suboptimal conditions some strains may grow very slowly, and incubation times may need to be extended to five days or more.

In Activity 2, you will be testing environmental samples of your choice for their ability to inhibit the growth of bacteria cultures (Escherichia coli, Micrococcus luteus, Serratia marcesens, or Staphylococcus epidermidis). Consider where each species of bacteria that you have in culture and where they are naturally occurring. As was described in the background section, many phages are species specific. What is your hypothesis? Research where the species you have are naturally occurring and create a hypothesis. Record your predictions about which samples will result in formation, suggest what phages maybe present, in Pre-Lab Data Table 1. You will collect data and make observations in this lab that will allow you to test your hypothesis.

pageData.text: You will need to choose four different locations to collect samples to test for phages that maybe in the environment. Use four of your plastic collection cups with lids to collect water from a stream, lake, creek, mud puddle, or pond. You may choose to collect from different areas around the same body of water. For example, if you are collecting from a lake, is there a muddy spot and clear spot that you could collect two different samples from.

If you chose to collect a soil sample instead of a water samples, fill your collection cup about halfway full of your sample and fill the cup with bottled water, shake it up, and allow it sit for at least 2 hours before proceeding to Step 5, filtering environmental samples.

Note: Based on Pre-lab experimental design, you may chosen to collect one environmental sample and test it for phage activity against all four stains. Refer back to your hypothesis to ensure you collecting the correct samples and recall what bacterial species you will testing and why.
Make sure you label each of your four your samples with an identifying name and the date. For example, “muddy pond water 7/14”, “clear lake water 7/14”, “compost water, 7/14”, and “park water, 7/14”

Caution: To reduce the risk of cultivating human pathogens, avoid sampling sites such as toilet seats, soles of shoes, nose or throat, or bodily fluids.
In Activity 1, you will prepare agar plates by melting and pouring the agar into the Petri dishes. You will use these prepared plates in Activity 2.

Clean the work area where you will pour your nutrient agar plates. Disinfect the area by applying your 10% bleach solution with a paper towel. Allow to air-dry (this will take approximately 2 minutes), as this increases the effectiveness of the disinfectant.
Caution: Make sure to loosen the caps, or pressure may build up in the bottles when heating, possibly causing an explosion hazard.
Slightly loosen the cap of a nutrient agar bottle (to allow steam to escape when heating).

Caution: To swirl the media, using an oven mitt or potholder, tighten the cap, and turn the bottle back and forth. If the media has not completely melted, loosen the cap, and microwave it for another 5 seconds. Repeat this process until the media is completely melted, continuously keeping an eye on the media to avoid any explosions.

Place a paper towel in the microwave. Place the bottle on the paper towel and warm it up in 5-second intervals. This step is very important to ensure the media does not explode in the microwave. Use an oven mitt or potholder to take the bottle with media out every 5 seconds and gently swirl the media in the bottle.
Allow the bottle to cool slightly before pouring the medium onto the plate. The medium should still be liquid, but the bottle should not be too hot to handle.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Photograph of cooled, melted agar being poured into a Petri dish with the lid lifted.

pageData.text: Note: While working, hold the agar bottle tilted at a 45° angle to exclude dust (Figure 5).
Caution: Do not place the bottles in an ice bath or refrigerator in an attempt to speed the cooling process.

Pour the agar into the plate, until the plate is approximately half full. This should be about one third of the agar in the bottle. Immediately replace the Petri dish lid. Pour the remaining agar into two more plates.
Allow at least 30 minutes for the plate to set. Do not disturb the plate during this time.
Repeat Steps 1–6 with the remaining agar bottle.

Photograph the agar plates after they have set. To photograph, place each plate, facing up, on a piece of white paper with your name and the date of plate preparation handwritten on it. (Include three agar plates in one photo.)

Once the plates have set for at least 30 minutes, invert them, and allow them to set for at least 1 more hour before proceeding to Activity 2. Alternatively, after an hour, the plates can be stored in the refrigerator for three days before use.
Dispose of the agar bottles and gloves in the garbage. Wash and dry your hands.

In Activity 2, you will add the control or filtered water samples to your prepared plates from Activity 1. You will then inoculate the plates with your chose bacteria and allow them to incubate. Finally, you will observe the plates for plaque formation.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Example of how plates might be labeled. Your labels may differ based on your hypothesis and experimental design. Refer to your pre-lab experimental design.

pageData.text: Note: To create the sterile water, you will need to boil approximately ¼ cup of tap or bottled water for 3-5 minutes.

Using a sterile transfer pipet, transfer approximately one milliliter of your sterile water to agar plate labeled “Control + Sterile Water.” The line right under the bulb of the pipette is approximately 1 milliliter.
Gently, rock the plate back and forth to ensure the filtered environmental sample covers the entire surface of the plate.
Let the plate sit with the lid side up for 10–15 minutes, or until no liquid is visible.
Repeat Steps 13-15 for the other water samples.
When all liquid has been absorbed into the agar, you can proceed to Step 18.
Mix the bacteria broth culture well by tightly capping the tube and tapping it or rolling it gently between your hands. Then, use a sterile swab to obtain broth from the tube.

Note: Part of correct aseptic technique is avoiding excessive removal of the lid from a Petri dish. Open the lid just enough to insert and move the swab and use the lid as a shield to keep dust off of the agar surface. Close the lid as soon as you are finished.

First, inoculate the “Control” plate. Turn the plate approximately 90°, and, without dipping the swab back into the bacteria culture tube, pull the swab again over the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern. Try not to miss any of the agar surface.
Repeat Step 19 two more times until you have swabbed the entire surface of the agar four times. Place the swab in the disposal jar.
Let the plate sit with the lid on and the agar side facing up. Invert the plate (place the plate lid-side down) and set it aside for incubation at room temperature.
Repeat Steps 18-11 above, for the rest of your agar plates.
Clean your work area as directed in Disposal and Cleanup.

After approximately 24 hours of incubation, examine your plates with the lids on. Do not remove the lids of the Petri dishes during any observations, as this may result in contamination. Record your observations in Data Table 2.

After 48-72 hours (about 2-3 days), the surface of the agar of the plates should be completely covered with bacterial growth, except for zones of clearing (). These may appear as glassy indents. text: To dispose of used inoculating tools (loops, pipettes, etc.), let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes, then pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running, and discard the materials in the garbage. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.

To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the tube or plate. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach.
Place the plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage. Be sure to wash your hands after removing your gloves.

After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the workspace with a 10% bleach solution. To remove bleach residue, clean the disinfected area with soap and water. Always wear PPE while disinfecting.
Collection cups, filters, and funnel can be disposed of in the household trash.

data.title: Antibiotic resistance
data.content: Microbes that are able to survive and even multiply in the presence of an antibiotic

data.title: Bacteriophage (phage)
data.content: A virus that infects and replicates within bacteria and archaea

data.title: Cell surface receptor
data.content: Transmembrane proteins embedded into the plasma membrane

data.title: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT)
data.content: Non-sexual movement of genetic information between organisms

data.title: Lysogenic cycle (non-virulent infection)
data.content: The phage injects its nucleic acid into the host, but does not casuse cell death

data.title: Lytic cycle
data.content: Production of new phage progeny and death of the host bacterial cell

data.title: Multi-drug resistance (MDR)
data.content: Microbes that have developed resistance to more than one antimicrobial agent

data.title: Pseudolysogeny cycle
data.content: During this type of infection the phage genome enters the cell in an unstable fashion and at some point, an environmental cue will trigger it to enter either the lysogenic or lytic cycle

data.title: Plaque
data.content: A localized absense or relative absence of bacterial growth which can be visible on solid or semi-solid media
